Practical Part 4

In the final part of the practical assessment you are to design and build a user interface that meets the following requirements:

Purpose:

a "course application" screen or similar that is asking an applicant to double check and confirm their details.

The screen needs to:

  • Shows user data including:
    • First, middle and last name
    • Address
    • Phone and cell phone
    • Email
    • Date of birth
    • Nationality
    • Primary and secondary next of kin details
      • Name
      • Address
      • Phone and cell
      • email
    • Avatar image
  • Allows user to edit any field in order to correct the data
  • Asks user to accept a "true and accurate" type of statement
  • Click button to confirm details are correct

The whole point is that there is a lot of data to display so you will need to think carefully about the best way to do it while allowing editing as well. Think outside the box!

Of course you are not just making a boring old desktop UI. It also needs to:

  • Be responsive
  • Be accessible
  • Be maintainable
  • Be secure
  • Follow UX best practices

But where will the data come from??

Use a free API like RandomUser. You can pull in multiple people to meet the Next of Kin requirements.

Note: you will probably be able to repurpose a bit this code in your final project.

FAQ

What happens after the data is submitted?
Nothing, there's no need to save it for this excercise. After the whole workflow is finished just return the user to the beginning.

Can I use a different API?
I guess so, as long as it meets the requirements.

Do I have to use Eleventy? Or SASS? Or some other technology?
Well, your code should meet best practices and be maintainable and scalable. It's kind of a "use your judgement" situation, but imagine if this needed to be expanded one day into a giant course application system or similar with menus and sidebars and bells and whistles.

How do I submit it?

Turns out that GitHub classroom has a mechanism for this already: you should commit all your changes to master and when you're finished just accept the pull request into the feedback branch. GitHub Classroom made it for us already!
